docs.lead_paragraph: I understand Thurow's screed against the "revolutionary" elderly. Though over 50, I have refused to give in to membership appeals by the A.A.R.P. precisely because of its obdurate stand on entitlements. But does Thurow know the same aging population I do? My friends are middle-class artists, intellectuals and professionals. A few are comfortable and secure as they approach, or exceed, 60. But many are increasingly insecure. Couples I know, prosperous and confident 10 years ago, have lost positions, apartments, their health and, for a period, health insurance. A friend who has worked all her life and thought herself secure with academic tenure lost her job when her department was abolished. Yet another friend lives in uncertainty after abandonment by her husband of three decades for a younger lover. When people this age are "downsized," the Social Security and Medicare programs stand between them and real terror.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE shrinkage of the great white-collar corporate institutions over the last five years has endangered a few institutions of another type: the C.E.O. belly, the wizened Walter Cronkite face of experience, the high forehead of a seasoned intellect, the furrowed brow of the thinking man. Now, in this age of downsizing, success must feel slightly uncomfortable, a world away from the fat-cat executive style savored by the fathers of today's corporate men. Executives are taking their hard-earned salaries and applying them in a way that executive-placement firms are endorsing: measures to look younger, with smooth skin, a full head of hair and a taut stomach. Unlike Calvin Klein underwear models with washboard stomachs, executives looking for jobs (or trying to hold onto them) don't have three hours a day to devote to the gym. What they do have, if they're working in one of these leaner and meaner companies, is more responsibility and the physiques that go with that stress. They complain about bags under their eyes, wrinkles, graying and thinning hair, rolls in the midsection.

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers added twice as many workers as had been expected to their payrolls in May, Government figures showed today, giving new signs that the economy has been picking up momentum. The report sent interest rates soaring and raised fears on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve might move soon to slow growth to prevent a jump in inflation. Business activity was so strong that economists were increasing their growth forecasts for the second quarter. And more than a half million additional people were drawn into the labor force. But since only two-thirds of them promptly found jobs, the unemployment rate edged up to 5.6 percent, the midpoint of the narrow range in which it has drifted since late 1994.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health insurance legislation, hailed six weeks ago by Senator Bob Dole as proof that Congress could overcome election-year stress to help ordinary Americans, foundered today on sharp disputes among Republicans and between Republicans and Democrats. The unpredictability of late-session Congressional behavior means that the measure is still barely alive. But today's developments appeared to doom the first serious effort at the kind of incremental health care change that politicians of both parties proclaimed would be preferable to the sweeping changes President Clinton proposed and Congress killed in 1994.
